segments.text: This is Deborah Beale, and I am interviewing Dr. W. Arthur Porter on the history of Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
The date is June 8th, 1984.
What I'd like to start with is just a brief biographical sketch of you and how you came to be associated with A&M and Peace.
Oh, okay.
Brief or long, whatever you want to make it.
Uh...
My association with A&M began in 1968 as an assistant professor of local engineering coming here from the semiconductor and R&D labs in Texas.
And you had a degree in electrical engineering?
No, I had degrees in physics, a bachelor's and a master's from North Texas, which I got
63 and 64 maybe.
I have to check the masters.
I think the masters were 64.
Then I came to Texas A&M for a Ph.D. in physics in 64.
I finished the coursework for my Ph.D. in physics in 66.
In those two years from 64 to 66 when I taught as
an instructor in both the physics and math departments during those two years, decided that I had been in the educational mode the moment I left Texas A&M.
I went to Texas A&M.
R&D lab.
Now, the bio that I saw, you said you had the PhD in interdisciplinary engineering.
Correct.
What is that?
That's a degree that's not used very often here at A&M, but it has been on the books.
And there is not a department of engineering here.
The department head rotates.
without any periodicity.
I think it's random.
From various departments.
I don't know how many degrees of interdisciplinary engineering have been given at Texas A&M.
It would be interesting to know that.
It's in the catalog.
It's an option.
But it's usually reserved for someone who has had
I think my situation was a good example.
I had completed the coursework for a Ph.D. in physics.
I had spent two years in a major industrial research laboratory.
I had a very specific dissertation research project that I was interested in doing.
And the coursework built around that discipline was very interdisciplinary.
It required an understanding of the basic laws of Mother Nature from the physical sense, which I had already done in my PhD work in physics.
It also demanded an understanding of the applications of those laws in several different areas of engineering, in electrical, chemical, materials.
So in 68, when I returned, when I really came to Texas A&M as a professor for the first time, having been a graduate student for two years before, I defined what I wanted to do to finish my PhD.
And it was suggested that what I needed to do was to do the interdisciplinary engineering degree.
I looked at it.
It sounded reasonable to me.
So I did it.
That I finished in 1970.

So really all I did was build on the experiences, educational experiences in physics by adding courses in electrical engineering at the Ph.D. level, mechanics and materials, in chemical engineering and gas dynamics,
did what we might otherwise call a Ph.D. and a half or two Ph.D.s at a court work.
And then did my dissertation.
And all of that time I was serving as an assistant professor.
And the association that you used to associate as a researcher at that time?
Sure.
The research course at that time, that was in 68 to 70,
The electrical engineering department, which also served as a division of teams, had very little research and was trying to build its first microelectronics program.
I believe that was what I was recruited from TI to do.
The question I was asked, I remember it well,
And even how I came to come back was I was here at A&M on campus recruiting North Texas instructors.

When I was asked to come over to the electrical engineering department to meet with some of the professors to advise them on how to spend $50,000 of TEAS money they had been given to start a microelectronics research group.
And so I met with him one afternoon, an afternoon when the interviewing was slow.
And that evening, the head of the department, Bill Jones, asked me if I would consider coming as a member of the faculty, which I turned down.
And it was about three or four months later, after he continued to contact me about would you do this or would you do that,
and kept saying, would you come and join us?
But I finally decided that if I was going to finish my Ph.D., that would be about as optimal a way as I was going to run into it.
I was working on it, still in physics, at night at North Texas State.
And I'm trying to do that for Dallas.
It's tough.
So...
It was...
June of 68, I decided to leave TI.
I took a leave.
I just took a leave.
You were just going to set it up and go back?
I was just going to set it up, finish my PhD, and go back to TI.
And then in 70, when I finished my PhD and we had the lab set up, I had written a proposal to NASA for a research conference.
which almost coincided with the granting of my degree.
The very first research contract in electrical engineering was awarded to me.
Here at A&M?
From NASA.
And so then I was faced with the decision of whether to stay at A&M.
Was there a research contract that was awarded to you?
Yes.
So it couldn't be passed on?
That's right.
I had written the proposal.
This was to the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama.
Looking at the potential advantages.
There were two thrusts of the contract, as I recall it.

One was to try to establish concretely the effects of processing these defects, those defects that are induced during the process of building an integrated circuit, or the yield and reliability of the circuit.
And my dissertation, what I had gotten interested in at Temple Central was a technique for controlling, preventing,
And then the potential advantages of going to space to build the semiconductor integrated circuit devices to avoid those effects.
So that's kind of the two career paths we crossed.
There was an intersection at the time of my graduation, completion of my Ph.D.
The NASA contract was awarded.
The option to go back to Texas estimates was there.
And Texas A&M was saying, don't go.
So all of that was, it turned out to be an economically down
The final decision was TI asked me to stay on leave if I wasn't going to return.
As long as I was staying at Texas A&M, TI was satisfied.
Fred Busey had called me
He was then the vice president of TI, in charge of the Civic Energy Division.
He said, do me one favor, if you leave Texas A&M, do not take another industrial job without letting me know about it.
But as long as I was willing to stay at A&M,
and work on the national research contract and continue to build the research program here.
They were quite comfortable with me staying on leave from PI and staying at A&M.
And that's ultimately what I did.
And I stayed on leave from PI until somewhere in the mid-70s when I finally decided I wasn't going to go back.
So you were the first director of the Institute of Solid State?
No.
How did that get set up?
There were five or six of us in electrical engineering that loosely formed what you'd have to call the solid state microelectronics group, or faculty.
The decision was made in the department that if we had an institute, a formal institute,

administratively structured that the visibility that we would present to the outside world would be better and that we could compete more effectively for research contracts and graduate students and so forth.
So the decision was made, Boolean Tees, with Bill Jones, who was head of the department in the division of Tees, to create the institute.
And that was made, I believe, prior to even my completion.
I'm not sure.
Very, very close to the time.
I've had to look at it.
At the time, it seemed just exactly what was written.
But Roman Hayden was the first director of ISSE, of the Institute for Solid State Electronics.
And he served as the director until I took over.
And I don't even remember.
Okay.
So the Institute, the Solid State Institute, or the Institute for Solid State Electronics, was probably created about 70.
I'm guessing.
You may know that or not.
Yeah.
We enrolled and took the...
When he left Texas A&M to become the chairman of the W department, I think at Oklahoma, he now serves as the dean of engineering at Arizona State.
I don't know where he is now.
I'm not sure where he went, but he left.
And I was asked to take over the directorship of the Institute for Scholarly Studies at Clarkson.
I was the second director.
Did that take much of the administrative work?
Initially,
Well, nothing like this job.
We were about five faculty members.
Probably no more than five graduate students.
Maybe 10, but I don't believe there were any at the PhD level.
All at the master's level.
Might have been one in there somewhere at the PhD level.
But very small.

So the administrative work that it took on my part was just trying to structure and define and give visibility to an entity that was a mental creation that was in the process of being physically structured.
But see, we were still putting all this together over an old bolted wall.
We were trying to build out of two-by-fours and sheet-like, what you'd call a high-tech research object.
When did you get out of there?
When the Zachary Engineering Center was completed, we moved from Baltimore to Zachary.
And I think Zachary must be about 12 years old now.
That would have been about 70.
No, Zachary must not be.
He must have been.
74 or somewhere like that.
Yeah, well, whatever that is, when we moved and we had designed, been able to design into Zachary, really some first class facilities.
Is that the way Zachary was constructed, or was every department and institute got to design its own?
Well, not every, but all of those that were in there.
I think there were five.
But I mean, all the ones that were going to move in got to design their own?
That's right.
So it wasn't an outside effort to... No, that's right.
As a matter of fact,
The person who really designed the facility, the institute, was Robert Hayden.
He was the interface person.
Did your involvement with TEAS change?
I know it did change between 72 and 79.
Well, as ISSE grew, the amount of administrative work, we were, at the time, I was asked to come in to tease.
to become the director of TV.
That was in, actually it was in August of 79.
Yeah.
Okay, so as director or as assistant director?
Well, I was asked to come as the director, but the evolution of that was to be the assistant director for a few months, and then in the
spring of 80, take over as director.
But to serve as the assistant director, find where the restroom is and kind of get your feet on the ground for a few months and then become the director.
And that proposal was made to me.
Actually in August of 1979.
I remember it well because I was just about to leave on a trip to the PNC.
There were eight or ten of us local engineers from around the nation who had been invited by China to come and give lectures throughout the country.
We were going to spend about a month
And about two weeks before I was to leave, I was called out by the dean of the College of Engineering and director of TEJ, Fred Benson, and presented with his proposal.
So did you get to go to the PRC?
Oh, sure.
Okay.
They didn't make you?
But I was asked to make my mind up.
or whether or not I would accept the position so that it would become effective on the 1st of September.
Which really gave me something like two weeks.
It was somewhere around the middle of August.
So this wasn't a job you did or made or got after this was just passed up?
No, and it came completely off the wall to me.
It was the second time I arrived in approach to the Indian system to take on a major administrative responsibility.
What was the position?
As president of the Research Foundation, which had... Wasn't he, didn't Benson have that position then?
He may have had that position then, too.
But when J. Llewellyn, Dr. Llewellyn, had left as the president of the Research Foundation,
I was approached to take over that position.
And I had turned that day home.
And so, after

Intensive meetings with the president of the university, who was at that time George Miller, and the new dean of engineering, who at that time was Bob Page, to get their sense of whether or not it was the right move for me to leave the directorship of this union.
take on the Directorship of Tees, Vis-a-Vis, coming in as Assistant Director for a few months and then going into the Directorship.
With their encouragement to do it, I agreed to it.
And then I went to China.
Did you, was your experience before then limited to ISSE or had you gotten into any of the other TEAS programs and research groups?
Oh, at that time, of course by that time ISSE had grown into a much more substantive and definable research entity, which was taken considerable amount of my time.
As a matter of fact, it was to the point where I had really very little time to spend in the laboratory myself.
I sat right next to it.
Graduate students were essentially the hands and legs of the work in the laboratory.
But that change was pretty dramatic.
When was it, 72, did you say?
From 72 to 79, that seven-year period, a lot of the nuts and bolts of literally installing the equipment, I had done myself.
And many, many of the measurements, the experiments, not just their design and the strategy of how to carry them out and the analysis of the results,
but the actual carrying out of the experiments I had done myself.
Because we were building for nothing.
No space, no facilities, no equipment, no students.
As they say, no nothing.
And so it was...
tracking from 68 particularly to 70, that 11 year period, we had come from, and starting with me, how would you spend $50,000 to get started if you had it?
Was it $50,000 in Teesman or was it Grant?
No, Teesman.
But Tease had put $50,000, but sitting here today talking about that is a joke.
It's funny.
At the time, in 1968, for $50,000, you could buy a respectable amount of equipment, which we did, enough to get started.
Well, we bought, I think, four furnaces.
a very fine microscope and the basic photolithographic equipment to have a dark room.
You could buy one furnace today for $50,000.
The laboratory over there is worth probably well in excess of $5 million.
It may be more than that.
It's probably closer to $10,000 to $20,000.
There are two laser systems over there that are worth half a million dollars each.
Is it ever an interdisciplinary program?
It was confined.
Its target was to support the research and graduate education.

in the microelectronics area and we had selected the engineering from a search point associated with the actual fabrication manufacturing of the integrated circuit so really it was the device physics and so we were had built a strong group associated with the
the really front end part of the process as opposed to the circuit design part of the process.
And that was a conscious decision because the major universities that had to jump on Texas A&M, places like Stanford, Cal Berkeley, had already staked out a pretty
substantial claim in the circuit design, but there wasn't any university really targeting its efforts on studying the device physics aspects associated with building the head-right circuit.
So that's where we focused our attention.
Is there any work done with the remote sensing center, or is that fairly different?
The remote sensing center was leaked
also to the electrical engineering division.
And because of the natural colleague relationship, the head of the remote sensing center was John Rouse, who, as a matter of fact, came to Texas A&M at the same time I did, in 1968.
He's now the dean of engineering at UT Arlington and serving as head of the division of T's, as a matter of fact.
So we had regular communication just because we were professors in the same department.
And we would work jointly on research projects where the expertise of ISSE and the remote sensing center could be combined.
So in that sense, I think all of our research programs here are interdisciplinary in nature.
We work with the physics department, with the chemistry department, regularly.
When our resources, our capabilities, our facilities could supply a need or satisfy a need, we always were open.
We worked with the nuclear engineering, still do.
ISI has a number of interrelationships, interdisciplinary activities where it is supportive of other programs and other programs support itself.
Did that flexibility ever change when the administrative changes, either as Chancellor or President?
No, I don't think so.
That flexibility, the flexibility to do it?
No, because it's a program in the Engineering Interim Station, and the Engineering Interim Station is kind of a melting pot of interdisciplinary activities.
I don't think that there's never been a disincentive from the engineering experiment station's point of view.
No, I don't believe there's ever been any administrator that I've known at least or that I've known if he's had or she that desire.
It's not been evident to me.

The strength, in my opinion, and I think this is shared by all of us in higher education, what happens, although none of us understand it, but what happens in a university atmosphere and a university campus comes from getting out of people's way and letting creative minds work together.
And if you start trying to edict a person in a

narrow otherwise narrowly defined discipline can never go over and interact with a person in a different but narrowly defined discipline i think that would be suicide to what i think happens in an academic but no one's ever tried it it has been tried at other places no one's no no no one's come in and tried to mark up the works i wouldn't say that i i won't say that
All I can say is that I don't know of anybody who consciously tried to do that.

Now, anytime you reorganize a place, and this place does it regularly, I think it's constantly undergoing re-organization, the desire on almost all of our hearts to, what I would say, control your own destiny,

Most of us, particularly in higher education, we are in higher education in a collection of big egos, generally talented people, bright people who have a desire to make a contribution and hence a desire to make their own contribution and have that recognized.
And that's the ego part.
And that's very desirable, I think.
So to the extent that any kind of administrative structure is perceived, whether it is in point of fact or not, or might have been, or might have worked, if given the chance,

If it is perceived by an individual to interfere with that person's, much less entity of a department or an institute or a division, ability or right to control their own destiny, then that perception will cause problems.
come to rest at the administration's doorstep.
Has there been any particularly low-part point in the peace history since you've been involved with it?
Oh, yes, absolutely.
Well, I don't say that they had to turn around and evaluate themselves, but between the time I agreed to become the director of TEES in late August of 79, and at that time,
The system organization structure was, TEAS was reporting to the president of Texas A&M University.
Fred Benson was the vice president for engineering and non-renewable resources, if I recall the time.
And TEAS reported to the president through that vice president.
I was gone for a little over a month actually.
I was given a paper in a conference in Germany.
At any rate, by the time I got back from China, the reorganization of the system was underway.
Unknown to me.
And I found myself in the mode of
having been, quote, ordained the director to be of needs of a part of the system that was finding itself now structured differently in the AM system than it was.
I had no...
way, really, to judge what that meant, what it might mean, or what it might be perceived to mean.
But it was a very traumatic period for the system.
All I had to do was be a casual observer.
And so, I would say the whole period of my directorship has been rather interesting, from this administrative organization, or reorganization,
and the perception of what that means.
How does it turn out to be perceived?
It depends upon the eyes of the holder.
It's like a painting.
My personal philosophy is that you can draw lines on paper and say this office reports to this office and this office interacts with this office
And about the best you can do with all of that is make it difficult for it to work.
But if you've got people with common objectives, you cannot structure a place.
You'd have to work so hard, consciously, to destroy it, to overcome the desire and will of those people, regardless of where you placed them and how you drew the lines.
They're going to get the job done.
I do think you can organize a place, however, to simplify how those good people can get the job done.
But it's virtually impossible if you really have good, dedicated people with common values to start with.
So is the TEAS reorganization a part of the whole system reorganization that took place?
Yes, that's right.
So you were going through the same threads everyone else was going through?
Oh, you bet.
And I really had no idea personally what all that meant.
What was clear, it was resisted by the university, Texas A&M University, did not want to see
the engineering experiment station moved out from under the chain of command of the university.
It was the will of the board to have the system reorganized.
And the details of why, I have no idea.
Nobody asked me.
As a matter of fact, the decision was made while I was out of the country.
And I frankly didn't know on a personal basis what it might mean or be perceived as I came back and was told that this reorganization was imminent and in process.
Of course, it's a matter of history what happened.
And I just,
Having made the mill commitment and the professional commitment to try to grab hold of the range of keys and try to build a research property that would make a difference for this state.
Decided to hang on to the range and see if I could keep the wagon between the ditches.
But there were some clear ditches and some big potholes.
You know, I'd turn a curve and see if there would be one.
I hadn't had a slightest idea it was going to be there or why it was there.
It would be a good shot.
Yeah, yeah.
Was the period when you acted as vice director, was that helpful to you?
Sure, absolutely.
And absolutely necessary.
It's a complex...

growing organization that's a now because of the pressures on the state part of it was at that time part of a very complex and rapidly growing system of critical importance to this thing this land grant university system in my opinion is and should be
the brightest star in the crown of Texas.
Was this during the Texas 2000 Commission?
Well, no, not at that time.
That happened during Governor Clements' period as governor.
But that did happen and did come to a final form during the period while I've been the director of teams, and I got very actively involved in that.
Did the original findings of the commission shock teams as to how little it was actually known about it?
Well, it didn't shock teams, I would think.
One of the things I was told and encouraged to do as the time gets past and something like this, usually the guy who had run it will drop a pearl or two for the guy who's taking it over.
But I was encouraged that all of us at the time to try to make these more visible in the state.
So that, first of all, it would be clear to the entities, the citizens of the state, how to access TEAS.
And it would also give TEAS greater visibility so that the legislators, the leadership of Texas would understand its value and potential.
And it's helping gain the support it needed in order to do the job it can do.

So because I had been told that that was, in almost everybody's opinion, something that needed now to be done for this agency, I wasn't shocked in the Texas 2000 study to know or to learn that Tease was not known or understood.
Tease is not known or understood in Texas A&M University.
Still isn't.
It's known now.
It's become very visible, very active, and it's grown at an incredible pace.
But it's not understood.
It's perceived often to be things it isn't.
And typically, when things are not understood, they're feared.
It's a human nature.
Is that one of your major programs is trying to get peace understood within the system itself?
Absolutely, sure.
All people that have a need or an opportunity or a desire to work through teens.
My philosophy is, as an educator, the more everybody knows, the better off we all are.
And a difference of opinion, in my opinion, is healthy, as long as we keep it in perspective and keep it constructive.
So no, I was not surprised.
But when I saw the recommendations, the first report of the Texas 2000, I didn't sit around and wring my hand.
I went immediately to the person who was responsible for having written that and told them that, first of all, I didn't appreciate it.
Secondly, the reason I didn't appreciate it was because it was incorrect.
And thirdly, I'd be happy to share with him why I felt that way and get his opinion.
Did that commission really make it easier for you to become this way?
Has it brought it out in the open?
I think that that helped.
Because when I said those things to Vic Arnold, actually, who was heading up the Texas 2000 Commission,
at least the working end of it.
And I mean by that, he was the person who had the responsibility, literally, for the staff that was pulling all the staff together.
He was surprised.
I just challenged him.
He was receptive.
And I said, all right, I'd like to hear.
So I immediately set up a meeting with him the very next week.
Went to Austin.
And we sat down, and he told me some of the thoughts he had about how to build a program, define a program, get it funded, to try to help create new businesses for the state.
We had NTs already begun to work on the Institute for Ventures and Technology earlier.
We didn't have that name for it at that time.
We were still calling it the Small Business Development Center or something like that.
But we had the concept well defined.
We already had the proposal in the NSF.
And we were moving.
We weren't talking about an idea that we were thinking about getting ready to define.
We already were moving on.
And in a meeting of the 2,000 that identified, I think, seven areas of critical importance to the state, one of which was research and development, and in a meeting at LTV, I think one of theirs,
of that R&D committee.
I was then invited the following week to come make the presentation of this idea and how it would function and how it would be funded through the governor's R&D committee.
And we were ready.
And I took Bill Muse, who was then the dean of the College of Business, who had been working from the outset in the proposal preparation.
And he and I and Jane Armstrong, who was then my assistant, went to that meeting and laid out the proposal.
And there was just a dramatic turnaround.
in the concept of how the state might proceed to accomplish that.
And I think that gave T's visibility.
What about the N, MCC?
Well,
Of course, you know what NCC is and how it came about.
Well, some of them.
But briefly, it was an idea of one man, as most ideas are.
Although it's hard to have a unique one.
You can often then find out who the other men were that might have had it about the same time.
But Bill Lawrence, who's the Chairman of the Board of the Controlled Danical Commission, had been pushing a concept like the NMCC.
